Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was a feast like Egypt 
had never seen before. The warrior god Set and his wife, 
the goddess Nephtys, decorated an extravagant hall 
for the occasion, with a beautiful wooden chest 
as the centerpiece. They invited all the most important gods,
dozens of lesser deities, and foreign monarchs. But no one caused as big a stir as Set 
and Nephtys’s older brother Osiris, the god who ruled all of Egypt 
and had brought prosperity to everyone. Set announced a game— whoever could fit perfectly in the chest
could have it as a gift. One by one, the guests clambered in,
but no one fit. Finally, it was Osiris’s turn. As he lay down, everyone could see
it was a perfect fit— another win for the god 
who could do no wrong. Then Set slammed the lid down 
with Osiris still inside, sealed it shut, and tossed it into the Nile. The chest was a coffin. Set had constructed it specifically 
to trap his brother and planned the party to lure him into it. Set had long been jealous 
of his brother’s successful reign, and hoped to replace 
him as the ruler of all Egypt. The Nile bore the coffin out to sea 
and it drifted for many days before washing ashore near Byblos, 
where a great cedar grew around it. The essence of the god within 
gave the tree a divine aura, and when the king of Byblos noticed it, he ordered the tree cut down
and brought to his palace. Unbeknownst to him, the coffin containing Egypt’s 
most powerful god was still inside. Set’s victory seemed complete, 
but he hadn’t counted on his sisters. Set’s wife Nephtys was also his sister, while their other sister, 
the goddess Isis, was married to their brother Osiris. Isis was determined to find Osiris, and enlisted Nephtys’s help 
behind Set’s back. The two sisters took the shape 
of falcons and travelled far and wide. Some children who had seen 
the coffin float by pointed them to the palace of Byblos. Isis adopted a new disguise 
and approached the palace. The queen was so charmed 
by the disguised goddess that she entrusted her 
with nursing the baby prince. Isis decided to make the child immortal 
by bathing him in flame. When the horrified queen 
came upon this scene, Isis revealed herself 
and demanded the tree. When she cut the coffin from the trunk
and opened it, Osiris was dead inside. Weeping, she carried his body 
back to Egypt and hid it in a swamp, while she set off in search 
of a means of resurrecting him. But while she was gone, Set found the body 
and cut it into many pieces, scattering them throughout Egypt. Isis had lost Osiris for the second time,
but she did not give up. She searched all over the land,
traveling in a boat of papyrus. One by one, she tracked down 
the parts of her husband’s dismembered body
in every province of Egypt, holding a funeral for each piece. At long last, she had recovered
every piece but one— his penis, 
which a fish in the Nile had eaten. Working with what she had, Isis 
reconstructed and revived her husband. But without his penis, 
Osiris was incomplete. He could not remain among the living, could not return to his old position 
as ruler of Egypt. Instead, he would have to rule over Duat,
the realm of the dead. Before he went, though, he and Isis 
conceived a son to bear Osiris’s legacy— and one day, avenge him.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was Set the god of...
Options: A. Warfare, B. The underworld, C. The harvest
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was the ruler of all Egypt before Set's plan to replace him? Options: A. Set, B. Osiris, C. Nephtys, D. Isis Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the purpose of the party thrown by Set and Nephtys? Options: A. To celebrate the prosperity of Egypt, B. To honor the gods, C. To invite foreign monarchs, D. To lure Osiris into the chest Correct Option: D
Question 3: What happened to Osiris after he was sealed inside the chest? Options: A. He was thrown into the Nile and the chest drifted to Byblos, B. He was freed by Set, C. He was taken to Egypt, D. He was resurrected by Isis Correct Option: A
Question 4: What was discovered inside the cedar tree when it was cut down in Byblos? Options: A. The tree's trunk was hollow, B. The tree was infested with insects, C. The coffin containing Osiris was still inside the tree, D. The tree was decayed Correct Option: C
Question 5: Who helped Isis find Osiris in Byblos, and what was the source of their information? Options: A. Nephtys, through a vision, B. Set, through a dream, C. The children who had seen the coffin float by, D. Isis's intuition Correct Option: C
Question 6: What did Isis do to the baby prince in Byblos to make him immortal? Options: A. She fed him special food, B. She gave him a magical amulet, C. She made him immortal by bathing him in flame, D. She left him in the palace Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the consequence of Osiris's body being cut into many pieces by Set? Options: A. Isis was able to resurrect him easily, B. Isis was able to find all the pieces easily, C. Isis was unable to find one piece of his body, which was eaten by a fish, D. Isis was unable to find the last piece of his body Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the result of Isis's efforts to resurrect Osiris? Options: A. He was able to return to his old position as ruler of Egypt, B. He was able to rule over Duat, C. He was able to live among the living, D. He was able to avenge himself against Set Correct Option: B
Question 9: Who was the father of the son conceived by Osiris and Isis? Options: A. Set, B. Osiris, C. Isis, D. The king of Byblos Correct Option: B
Question 10: What was the purpose of the son conceived by Osiris and Isis? Options: A. To bear Osiris's legacy, B. To avenge Osiris, C. To rule over Egypt, D. To resurrect Osiris Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, Question 1 is the most similar in terms of intent and relevance to the topic.

The ground truth MCQ asks about Set's role as a god, while Question 1 asks about the ruler of Egypt before Set's plan, which is related to Set's actions and motivations. Although the questions are not identical, Question 1 is the closest match in terms of context and intent.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was a feast like Egypt 
had never seen before. The warrior god Set and his wife, 
the goddess Nephtys, decorated an extravagant hall 
for the occasion, with a beautiful wooden chest 
as the centerpiece. They invited all the most important gods,
dozens of lesser deities, and foreign monarchs. But no one caused as big a stir as Set 
and Nephtys’s older brother Osiris, the god who ruled all of Egypt 
and had brought prosperity to everyone. Set announced a game— whoever could fit perfectly in the chest
could have it as a gift. One by one, the guests clambered in,
but no one fit. Finally, it was Osiris’s turn. As he lay down, everyone could see
it was a perfect fit— another win for the god 
who could do no wrong. Then Set slammed the lid down 
with Osiris still inside, sealed it shut, and tossed it into the Nile. The chest was a coffin. Set had constructed it specifically 
to trap his brother and planned the party to lure him into it. Set had long been jealous 
of his brother’s successful reign, and hoped to replace 
him as the ruler of all Egypt. The Nile bore the coffin out to sea 
and it drifted for many days before washing ashore near Byblos, 
where a great cedar grew around it. The essence of the god within 
gave the tree a divine aura, and when the king of Byblos noticed it, he ordered the tree cut down
and brought to his palace. Unbeknownst to him, the coffin containing Egypt’s 
most powerful god was still inside. Set’s victory seemed complete, 
but he hadn’t counted on his sisters. Set’s wife Nephtys was also his sister, while their other sister, 
the goddess Isis, was married to their brother Osiris. Isis was determined to find Osiris, and enlisted Nephtys’s help 
behind Set’s back. The two sisters took the shape 
of falcons and travelled far and wide. Some children who had seen 
the coffin float by pointed them to the palace of Byblos. Isis adopted a new disguise 
and approached the palace. The queen was so charmed 
by the disguised goddess that she entrusted her 
with nursing the baby prince. Isis decided to make the child immortal 
by bathing him in flame. When the horrified queen 
came upon this scene, Isis revealed herself 
and demanded the tree. When she cut the coffin from the trunk
and opened it, Osiris was dead inside. Weeping, she carried his body 
back to Egypt and hid it in a swamp, while she set off in search 
of a means of resurrecting him. But while she was gone, Set found the body 
and cut it into many pieces, scattering them throughout Egypt. Isis had lost Osiris for the second time,
but she did not give up. She searched all over the land,
traveling in a boat of papyrus. One by one, she tracked down 
the parts of her husband’s dismembered body
in every province of Egypt, holding a funeral for each piece. At long last, she had recovered
every piece but one— his penis, 
which a fish in the Nile had eaten. Working with what she had, Isis 
reconstructed and revived her husband. But without his penis, 
Osiris was incomplete. He could not remain among the living, could not return to his old position 
as ruler of Egypt. Instead, he would have to rule over Duat,
the realm of the dead. Before he went, though, he and Isis 
conceived a son to bear Osiris’s legacy— and one day, avenge him.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who was Set’s wife?
Options: A. Isis, B. Duat, C. Nephtys
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was a feast like Egypt 
had never seen before. The warrior god Set and his wife, 
the goddess Nephtys, decorated an extravagant hall 
for the occasion, with a beautiful wooden chest 
as the centerpiece. They invited all the most important gods,
dozens of lesser deities, and foreign monarchs. But no one caused as big a stir as Set 
and Nephtys’s older brother Osiris, the god who ruled all of Egypt 
and had brought prosperity to everyone. Set announced a game— whoever could fit perfectly in the chest
could have it as a gift. One by one, the guests clambered in,
but no one fit. Finally, it was Osiris’s turn. As he lay down, everyone could see
it was a perfect fit— another win for the god 
who could do no wrong. Then Set slammed the lid down 
with Osiris still inside, sealed it shut, and tossed it into the Nile. The chest was a coffin. Set had constructed it specifically 
to trap his brother and planned the party to lure him into it. Set had long been jealous 
of his brother’s successful reign, and hoped to replace 
him as the ruler of all Egypt. The Nile bore the coffin out to sea 
and it drifted for many days before washing ashore near Byblos, 
where a great cedar grew around it. The essence of the god within 
gave the tree a divine aura, and when the king of Byblos noticed it, he ordered the tree cut down
and brought to his palace. Unbeknownst to him, the coffin containing Egypt’s 
most powerful god was still inside. Set’s victory seemed complete, 
but he hadn’t counted on his sisters. Set’s wife Nephtys was also his sister, while their other sister, 
the goddess Isis, was married to their brother Osiris. Isis was determined to find Osiris, and enlisted Nephtys’s help 
behind Set’s back. The two sisters took the shape 
of falcons and travelled far and wide. Some children who had seen 
the coffin float by pointed them to the palace of Byblos. Isis adopted a new disguise 
and approached the palace. The queen was so charmed 
by the disguised goddess that she entrusted her 
with nursing the baby prince. Isis decided to make the child immortal 
by bathing him in flame. When the horrified queen 
came upon this scene, Isis revealed herself 
and demanded the tree. When she cut the coffin from the trunk
and opened it, Osiris was dead inside. Weeping, she carried his body 
back to Egypt and hid it in a swamp, while she set off in search 
of a means of resurrecting him. But while she was gone, Set found the body 
and cut it into many pieces, scattering them throughout Egypt. Isis had lost Osiris for the second time,
but she did not give up. She searched all over the land,
traveling in a boat of papyrus. One by one, she tracked down 
the parts of her husband’s dismembered body
in every province of Egypt, holding a funeral for each piece. At long last, she had recovered
every piece but one— his penis, 
which a fish in the Nile had eaten. Working with what she had, Isis 
reconstructed and revived her husband. But without his penis, 
Osiris was incomplete. He could not remain among the living, could not return to his old position 
as ruler of Egypt. Instead, he would have to rule over Duat,
the realm of the dead. Before he went, though, he and Isis 
conceived a son to bear Osiris’s legacy— and one day, avenge him.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was used to imprison Osiris?
Options: A. A golden cage, B. An ornate coffin, C. A sealed cave
Correct Option: B

Question 4: What was discovered inside the cedar tree when it was cut down in Byblos? Options: A. The tree's trunk was hollow, B. The tree was infested with insects, C. The coffin containing Osiris was still inside the tree, D. The tree was decayed Correct Option: C
Question 5: Who helped Isis find Osiris in Byblos, and what was the source of their information? Options: A. Nephtys, through a vision, B. Set, through a dream, C. The children who had seen the coffin float by, D. Isis's intuition Correct Option: C
Question 6: What did Isis do to the baby prince in Byblos to make him immortal? Options: A. She fed him special food, B. She gave him a magical amulet, C. She made him immortal by bathing him in flame, D. She left him in the palace Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the consequence of Osiris's body being cut into many pieces by Set? Options: A. Isis was able to resurrect him easily, B. Isis was able to find all the pieces easily, C. Isis was unable to find one piece of his body, which was eaten by a fish, D. Isis was unable to find the last piece of his body Correct Option: C

Question 9: Who was the father of the son conceived by Osiris and Isis? Options: A. Set, B. Osiris, C. Isis, D. The king of Byblos Correct Option: B
Question 10: What was the purpose of the son conceived by Osiris and Isis? Options: A. To bear Osiris's legacy, B. To avenge Osiris, C. To rule over Egypt, D. To resurrect Osiris Correct Option: A

It was a feast like Egypt 
had never seen before. The warrior god Set and his wife, 
the goddess Nephtys, decorated an extravagant hall 
for the occasion, with a beautiful wooden chest 
as the centerpiece. They invited all the most important gods,
dozens of lesser deities, and foreign monarchs. But no one caused as big a stir as Set 
and Nephtys’s older brother Osiris, the god who ruled all of Egypt 
and had brought prosperity to everyone. Set announced a game— whoever could fit perfectly in the chest
could have it as a gift. One by one, the guests clambered in,
but no one fit. Finally, it was Osiris’s turn. As he lay down, everyone could see
it was a perfect fit— another win for the god 
who could do no wrong. Then Set slammed the lid down 
with Osiris still inside, sealed it shut, and tossed it into the Nile. The chest was a coffin. Set had constructed it specifically 
to trap his brother and planned the party to lure him into it. Set had long been jealous 
of his brother’s successful reign, and hoped to replace 
him as the ruler of all Egypt. The Nile bore the coffin out to sea 
and it drifted for many days before washing ashore near Byblos, 
where a great cedar grew around it. The essence of the god within 
gave the tree a divine aura, and when the king of Byblos noticed it, he ordered the tree cut down
and brought to his palace. Unbeknownst to him, the coffin containing Egypt’s 
most powerful god was still inside. Set’s victory seemed complete, 
but he hadn’t counted on his sisters. Set’s wife Nephtys was also his sister, while their other sister, 
the goddess Isis, was married to their brother Osiris. Isis was determined to find Osiris, and enlisted Nephtys’s help 
behind Set’s back. The two sisters took the shape 
of falcons and travelled far and wide. Some children who had seen 
the coffin float by pointed them to the palace of Byblos. Isis adopted a new disguise 
and approached the palace. The queen was so charmed 
by the disguised goddess that she entrusted her 
with nursing the baby prince. Isis decided to make the child immortal 
by bathing him in flame. When the horrified queen 
came upon this scene, Isis revealed herself 
and demanded the tree. When she cut the coffin from the trunk
and opened it, Osiris was dead inside. Weeping, she carried his body 
back to Egypt and hid it in a swamp, while she set off in search 
of a means of resurrecting him. But while she was gone, Set found the body 
and cut it into many pieces, scattering them throughout Egypt. Isis had lost Osiris for the second time,
but she did not give up. She searched all over the land,
traveling in a boat of papyrus. One by one, she tracked down 
the parts of her husband’s dismembered body
in every province of Egypt, holding a funeral for each piece. At long last, she had recovered
every piece but one— his penis, 
which a fish in the Nile had eaten. Working with what she had, Isis 
reconstructed and revived her husband. But without his penis, 
Osiris was incomplete. He could not remain among the living, could not return to his old position 
as ruler of Egypt. Instead, he would have to rule over Duat,
the realm of the dead. Before he went, though, he and Isis 
conceived a son to bear Osiris’s legacy— and one day, avenge him.

It was a feast like Egypt 
had never seen before. The warrior god Set and his wife, 
the goddess Nephtys, decorated an extravagant hall 
for the occasion, with a beautiful wooden chest 
as the centerpiece. They invited all the most important gods,
dozens of lesser deities, and foreign monarchs. But no one caused as big a stir as Set 
and Nephtys’s older brother Osiris, the god who ruled all of Egypt 
and had brought prosperity to everyone. Set announced a game— whoever could fit perfectly in the chest
could have it as a gift. One by one, the guests clambered in,

it was a perfect fit— another win for the god 
who could do no wrong. Then Set slammed the lid down

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the sun-dappled streets 
of a small town, a proud mother 
showed off her newborn son. Upon noticing his lucky birthmark, townsfolk predicted 
he would marry a princess. But soon, these rumors reached the ears 
of the wicked king. Enraged, the king stole the child away, 
and sent him hurtling down the river. But the infant’s luck proved greater 
than the king’s plan. Years later, the king 
was traveling his realm, when he spotted a strapping young man 
with an uncanny birthmark. After confirming the child’s origins, the sly king entrusted the boy 
with a letter for the queen. The youth eagerly set out 
to deliver the message— not knowing he was carrying 
his own death sentence. That night, roaming bandits 
stumbled upon his camp. Yet when they read the brutal letter, 
they were filled with pity. Deciding to make trouble for the king 
instead, they scribbled a new note. As soon as the youth 
arrived at the palace, he locked eyes with the princess. The two felt destined for each other. And when the queen read 
that the king approved this union, she joyfully organized 
a whirlwind wedding. When the king returned, 
he was furious. But he couldn’t execute his daughter’s 
beloved without reason. So he devised a diabolical trial. He ordered the youth 
to travel to Hell itself, and return with three golden hairs 
freshly plucked from the Devil’s head. Only upon succeeding 
could he return to his bride. The youth searched across the land 
for the entrance to Hell, until he finally reached 
an eerie village. Here, he saw some villagers 
gathered around a well. They closed in on the youth, 
refusing to let him pass until he answered their question: 
why was the well dry? The youth replied, 
“I will answer when I return.” They directed him further into town, where he came across another set 
of villagers contemplating a gnarled tree. They refused to let him pass 
until he answered their question: why was the tree barren? Again, the youth responded, 
“I will answer when I return." These villagers guided him to the dock, 
where an elderly ferryman awaited. As he paddled through the black water, 
the ferryman rasped a third question: how can I escape my interminable task? Once more, the youth promised, 
“I will answer when I return.” At last, they reached a hut sinking 
into the swampy banks of Hell. Reluctantly, the youth knocked 
on the rotting door. The devil’s grandmother 
answered his call. She was known to help some visiting souls,
and harm others. The youth had just finished his story 
when they heard the devil’s footsteps. Without warning, 
the boy’s world appeared to shrink. The devil’s grandmother lifted him 
into the folds of her sleeve, and welcomed her grandson. The old woman set to work, 
lavishing the devil with food and drink. When he fell asleep, she deftly plucked 
three gleaming hairs from his head. With each plucked hair, the Devil briefly 
awoke and complained about his dreams, full of nearby villagers 
and their problems. The next morning, the youth departed— armed with three golden hairs, 
and three pieces of information. He shared the devil’s first dream 
with the ferryman. If the boatman could hand his oars 
to a willing passenger, he would be free from his task. Back at the village, the youth declared 
that there was a mouse gnawing at the root of the tree, 
and an enormous toad blocking the well. The villagers rewarded him handsomely 
for his help. Back from his journey, the youth thrust 
the devil’s hairs at the king— but his greedy father-in-law 
only had eyes for the gold. The sly youth told the king 
that even greater wealth awaited him across the river. Immediately, the king 
hastened to the riverbank. Eager to claim his riches, he held out his hands impatiently 
to the grinning ferryman— who happily handed over his oars.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Devil’s Grandmother helped the youth by transforming into a
Options: A. Bat, B. Teacup, C. Black ant, D. Spider
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the reason behind the wicked king's actions towards the newborn son? Options: A. He was jealous of the child's lucky birthmark., B. He wanted to claim the child as his own., C. The king feared the child would marry a princess and steal the throne., D. He was trying to protect the child from harm. Correct Option: C
Question 2: Who helped the youth by scribbling a new information on the letter meant for the queen? Options: A. The ferryman, B. The devil's grandmother, C. The bandits, D. The king Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the condition set by the king for the youth to return to his bride? Options: A. To bring back three golden hairs from the devil's head., B. To travel to the end of the world and back., C. To complete a series of tasks set by the devil's grandmother., D. To fight a duel with the king's champion. Correct Option: A
Question 4: What was the reason behind the devil's grandmother's actions towards the youth? Options: A. She was trying to help the youth complete his task., B. She was trying to harm the youth., C. She was trying to help her grandson, the devil, and trick the youth., D. She was trying to gain wealth and power. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the solution to the ferryman's problem, as revealed by the devil's first dream? Options: A. To build a new boat., B. To find a new oarsman., C. To hand his oars to a willing passenger., D. To sail to the other side of the river. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the reason behind the king's greed for the devil's hairs? Options: A. He wanted to use them to gain wealth and power., B. He wanted to use them to heal his daughter's illness., C. He wanted to use them to complete his task., D. He was blinded by the gold. Correct Option: D
Question 7: Who was the one who helped the youth by revealing the solution to the devil's grandmother's problem? Options: A. The ferryman, B. The devil's grandmother, C. The youth, D. The king Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the outcome of the king's actions after he received the devil's hairs? Options: A. He was able to free the ferryman from his task., B. He was able to gain wealth and power., C. He was able to complete his task and return to his daughter., D. He was tricked by the youth. Correct Option: D
Question 9: What was the reason behind the youth's actions towards the king after he received the devil's hairs? Options: A. He wanted to use the hairs to gain wealth and power., B. He wanted to use the hairs to complete his task., C. He wanted to trick the king and gain his freedom., D. He wanted to use the hairs to gain the devil's favor. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the outcome of the king's actions after he handed over his oars to the ferryman? Options: A. He was able to complete his task and return to his daughter., B. He was able to gain wealth and power., C. He was able to free the ferryman from his task., D. He was able to gain the devil's favor. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent.

However, I can suggest that the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is not present in the provided options. The ground truth MCQ is asking about the Devil's Grandmother helping the youth by transforming into a specific object or creature, but none of the generated MCQs address this specific topic.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the sun-dappled streets 
of a small town, a proud mother 
showed off her newborn son. Upon noticing his lucky birthmark, townsfolk predicted 
he would marry a princess. But soon, these rumors reached the ears 
of the wicked king. Enraged, the king stole the child away, 
and sent him hurtling down the river. But the infant’s luck proved greater 
than the king’s plan. Years later, the king 
was traveling his realm, when he spotted a strapping young man 
with an uncanny birthmark. After confirming the child’s origins, the sly king entrusted the boy 
with a letter for the queen. The youth eagerly set out 
to deliver the message— not knowing he was carrying 
his own death sentence. That night, roaming bandits 
stumbled upon his camp. Yet when they read the brutal letter, 
they were filled with pity. Deciding to make trouble for the king 
instead, they scribbled a new note. As soon as the youth 
arrived at the palace, he locked eyes with the princess. The two felt destined for each other. And when the queen read 
that the king approved this union, she joyfully organized 
a whirlwind wedding. When the king returned, 
he was furious. But he couldn’t execute his daughter’s 
beloved without reason. So he devised a diabolical trial. He ordered the youth 
to travel to Hell itself, and return with three golden hairs 
freshly plucked from the Devil’s head. Only upon succeeding 
could he return to his bride. The youth searched across the land 
for the entrance to Hell, until he finally reached 
an eerie village. Here, he saw some villagers 
gathered around a well. They closed in on the youth, 
refusing to let him pass until he answered their question: 
why was the well dry? The youth replied, 
“I will answer when I return.” They directed him further into town, where he came across another set 
of villagers contemplating a gnarled tree. They refused to let him pass 
until he answered their question: why was the tree barren? Again, the youth responded, 
“I will answer when I return." These villagers guided him to the dock, 
where an elderly ferryman awaited. As he paddled through the black water, 
the ferryman rasped a third question: how can I escape my interminable task? Once more, the youth promised, 
“I will answer when I return.” At last, they reached a hut sinking 
into the swampy banks of Hell. Reluctantly, the youth knocked 
on the rotting door. The devil’s grandmother 
answered his call. She was known to help some visiting souls,
and harm others. The youth had just finished his story 
when they heard the devil’s footsteps. Without warning, 
the boy’s world appeared to shrink. The devil’s grandmother lifted him 
into the folds of her sleeve, and welcomed her grandson. The old woman set to work, 
lavishing the devil with food and drink. When he fell asleep, she deftly plucked 
three gleaming hairs from his head. With each plucked hair, the Devil briefly 
awoke and complained about his dreams, full of nearby villagers 
and their problems. The next morning, the youth departed— armed with three golden hairs, 
and three pieces of information. He shared the devil’s first dream 
with the ferryman. If the boatman could hand his oars 
to a willing passenger, he would be free from his task. Back at the village, the youth declared 
that there was a mouse gnawing at the root of the tree, 
and an enormous toad blocking the well. The villagers rewarded him handsomely 
for his help. Back from his journey, the youth thrust 
the devil’s hairs at the king— but his greedy father-in-law 
only had eyes for the gold. The sly youth told the king 
that even greater wealth awaited him across the river. Immediately, the king 
hastened to the riverbank. Eager to claim his riches, he held out his hands impatiently 
to the grinning ferryman— who happily handed over his oars.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The baby’s distinguishing birthmark predicted that he would:
Options: A. Travel to hell and back, B. Marry a princess, C. Kill a king, D. Be rich beyond his wildest dreams
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the reason behind the wicked king's actions towards the newborn son? Options: A. He was jealous of the child's lucky birthmark., B. He wanted to claim the child as his own., C. The king feared the child would marry a princess and steal the throne., D. He was trying to protect the child from harm. Correct Option: C
Question 2: Who helped the youth by scribbling a new information on the letter meant for the queen? Options: A. The ferryman, B. The devil's grandmother, C. The bandits, D. The king Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the condition set by the king for the youth to return to his bride? Options: A. To bring back three golden hairs from the devil's head., B. To travel to the end of the world and back., C. To complete a series of tasks set by the devil's grandmother., D. To fight a duel with the king's champion. Correct Option: A
Question 4: What was the reason behind the devil's grandmother's actions towards the youth? Options: A. She was trying to help the youth complete his task., B. She was trying to harm the youth., C. She was trying to help her grandson, the devil, and trick the youth., D. She was trying to gain wealth and power. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the solution to the ferryman's problem, as revealed by the devil's first dream? Options: A. To build a new boat., B. To find a new oarsman., C. To hand his oars to a willing passenger., D. To sail to the other side of the river. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the reason behind the king's greed for the devil's hairs? Options: A. He wanted to use them to gain wealth and power., B. He wanted to use them to heal his daughter's illness., C. He wanted to use them to complete his task., D. He was blinded by the gold. Correct Option: D
Question 7: Who was the one who helped the youth by revealing the solution to the devil's grandmother's problem? Options: A. The ferryman, B. The devil's grandmother, C. The youth, D. The king Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the outcome of the king's actions after he received the devil's hairs? Options: A. He was able to free the ferryman from his task., B. He was able to gain wealth and power., C. He was able to complete his task and return to his daughter., D. He was tricked by the youth. Correct Option: D
Question 9: What was the reason behind the youth's actions towards the king after he received the devil's hairs? Options: A. He wanted to use the hairs to gain wealth and power., B. He wanted to use the hairs to complete his task., C. He wanted to trick the king and gain his freedom., D. He wanted to use the hairs to gain the devil's favor. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the outcome of the king's actions after he handed over his oars to the ferryman? Options: A. He was able to complete his task and return to his daughter., B. He was able to gain wealth and power., C. He was able to free the ferryman from his task., D. He was able to gain the devil's favor. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not an exact match, but Question 1 is the closest in terms of question intent and content.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the prediction made about the baby's future based on his birthmark, while Question 1 asks about the reason behind the king's actions towards the newborn son, which is related to the prediction.

Although not a perfect match, Question 1 is the closest generated MCQ that relates to the content and intent of the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1

Question 7: Who was the one who helped the youth by revealing the solution to the devil's grandmother's problem? Options: A. The ferryman, B. The devil's grandmother, C. The youth, D. The king Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the outcome of the king's actions after he received the devil's hairs? Options: A. He was able to free the ferryman from his task., B. He was able to gain wealth and power., C. He was able to complete his task and return to his daughter., D. He was tricked by the youth. Correct Option: D
Question 9: What was the reason behind the youth's actions towards the king after he received the devil's hairs? Options: A. He wanted to use the hairs to gain wealth and power., B. He wanted to use the hairs to complete his task., C. He wanted to trick the king and gain his freedom., D. He wanted to use the hairs to gain the devil's favor. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the outcome of the king's actions after he handed over his oars to the ferryman? Options: A. He was able to complete his task and return to his daughter., B. He was able to gain wealth and power., C. He was able to free the ferryman from his task., D. He was able to gain the devil's favor. Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the sun-dappled streets 
of a small town, a proud mother 
showed off her newborn son. Upon noticing his lucky birthmark, townsfolk predicted 
he would marry a princess. But soon, these rumors reached the ears 
of the wicked king. Enraged, the king stole the child away, 
and sent him hurtling down the river. But the infant’s luck proved greater 
than the king’s plan. Years later, the king 
was traveling his realm, when he spotted a strapping young man 
with an uncanny birthmark. After confirming the child’s origins, the sly king entrusted the boy 
with a letter for the queen. The youth eagerly set out 
to deliver the message— not knowing he was carrying 
his own death sentence. That night, roaming bandits 
stumbled upon his camp. Yet when they read the brutal letter, 
they were filled with pity. Deciding to make trouble for the king 
instead, they scribbled a new note. As soon as the youth 
arrived at the palace, he locked eyes with the princess. The two felt destined for each other. And when the queen read 
that the king approved this union, she joyfully organized 
a whirlwind wedding. When the king returned, 
he was furious. But he couldn’t execute his daughter’s 
beloved without reason. So he devised a diabolical trial. He ordered the youth 
to travel to Hell itself, and return with three golden hairs 
freshly plucked from the Devil’s head. Only upon succeeding 
could he return to his bride. The youth searched across the land 
for the entrance to Hell, until he finally reached 
an eerie village. Here, he saw some villagers 
gathered around a well. They closed in on the youth, 
refusing to let him pass until he answered their question: 
why was the well dry? The youth replied, 
“I will answer when I return.” They directed him further into town, where he came across another set 
of villagers contemplating a gnarled tree. They refused to let him pass 
until he answered their question: why was the tree barren? Again, the youth responded, 
“I will answer when I return." These villagers guided him to the dock, 
where an elderly ferryman awaited. As he paddled through the black water, 
the ferryman rasped a third question: how can I escape my interminable task? Once more, the youth promised, 
“I will answer when I return.” At last, they reached a hut sinking 
into the swampy banks of Hell. Reluctantly, the youth knocked 
on the rotting door. The devil’s grandmother 
answered his call. She was known to help some visiting souls,
and harm others. The youth had just finished his story 
when they heard the devil’s footsteps. Without warning, 
the boy’s world appeared to shrink. The devil’s grandmother lifted him 
into the folds of her sleeve, and welcomed her grandson. The old woman set to work, 
lavishing the devil with food and drink. When he fell asleep, she deftly plucked 
three gleaming hairs from his head. With each plucked hair, the Devil briefly 
awoke and complained about his dreams, full of nearby villagers 
and their problems. The next morning, the youth departed— armed with three golden hairs, 
and three pieces of information. He shared the devil’s first dream 
with the ferryman. If the boatman could hand his oars 
to a willing passenger, he would be free from his task. Back at the village, the youth declared 
that there was a mouse gnawing at the root of the tree, 
and an enormous toad blocking the well. The villagers rewarded him handsomely 
for his help. Back from his journey, the youth thrust 
the devil’s hairs at the king— but his greedy father-in-law 
only had eyes for the gold. The sly youth told the king 
that even greater wealth awaited him across the river. Immediately, the king 
hastened to the riverbank. Eager to claim his riches, he held out his hands impatiently 
to the grinning ferryman— who happily handed over his oars.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: After visiting the devil's grandmother, the youth discovered that the village well was dry because
Options: A. there was an enormous toad blocking the well, B. of seasonal drought, C. the villagers over-consumed water
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When Nicolas Bourbaki applied 
to the American Mathematical Society in the 1950s, he was already one of the most influential
mathematicians of his time. He’d published articles 
in international journals and his textbooks were required reading. Yet his application was firmly rejected 
for one simple reason— Nicolas Bourbaki did not exist. Two decades earlier, 
mathematics was in disarray. Many established mathematicians had lost 
their lives in the first World War, and the field had become fragmented. Different branches used disparate 
methodology to pursue their own goals. And the lack of a shared 
mathematical language made it difficult to share 
or expand their work. In 1934, a group of French mathematicians 
were particularly fed up. While studying at the prestigious 
École normale supérieure, they found the textbook 
for their calculus class so disjointed that they decided to write a better one. The small group 
quickly took on new members, and as the project grew, 
so did their ambition. The result was 
the "Éléments de mathématique," a treatise that sought to create 
a consistent logical framework unifying every branch of mathematics. The text began 
with a set of simple axioms— laws and assumptions it would use 
to build its argument. From there, its authors derived 
more and more complex theorems that corresponded with work 
being done across the field. But to truly reveal common ground, the group needed to identify 
consistent rules that applied to a wide range of problems. To accomplish this, they gave new, 
clear definitions to some of the most important 
mathematical objects, including the function. It’s reasonable to think of functions 
as machines that accept inputs and produce an output. But if we think of functions 
as bridges between two groups, we can start to make claims about 
the logical relationships between them. For example, consider a group of numbers
and a group of letters. We could define a function where 
every numerical input corresponds to the same alphabetical output, but this doesn’t establish 
a particularly interesting relationship. Alternatively, we could define a function 
where every numerical input corresponds to a different 
alphabetical output. This second function sets up 
a logical relationship where performing a process on the input 
has corresponding effects on its mapped output. The group began to define functions by how
they mapped elements across domains. If a function’s output came 
from a unique input, they defined it as injective. If every output can be mapped 
onto at least one input, the function was surjective. And in bijective functions, each element 
had perfect one to one correspondence. This allowed mathematicians to establish 
logic that could be translated across the function’s domains 
in both directions. Their systematic approach 
to abstract principles was in stark contrast to the popular 
belief that math was an intuitive science, and an over-dependence on logic 
constrained creativity. But this rebellious band of scholars 
gleefully ignored conventional wisdom. They were revolutionizing the field, 
and they wanted to mark the occasion with their biggest stunt yet. They decided to publish 
"Éléments de mathématique" and all their subsequent work 
under a collective pseudonym: Nicolas Bourbaki. Over the next two decades, Bourbaki’s 
publications became standard references. And the group’s members took their prank 
as seriously as their work. Their invented mathematician claimed 
to be a reclusive Russian genius who would only meet 
with his selected collaborators. They sent telegrams in Bourbaki’s name, 
announced his daughter’s wedding, and publicly insulted anyone 
who doubted his existence. In 1968, when they could 
no longer maintain the ruse, the group ended their joke 
the only way they could. They printed Bourbaki’s obituary,
complete with mathematical puns. Despite his apparent death, the group 
bearing Bourbaki’s name lives on today. Though he’s not associated 
with any single major discovery, Bourbaki’s influence informs 
much current research. And the modern emphasis on formal proofs
owes a great deal to his rigorous methods. Nicolas Bourbaki may have been imaginary— 
but his legacy is very real.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What to do when you find unsatisfactory scientific explanations (in textbooks and/or research papers): given it’s a field of your interest and you think you can do a better job?
Options: A. Complain about it, B. Give up and do something else, C. Do something about it: one option would be - Form a secret society, seriously do tangible work for years, publish your results under a collective pseudonym and change the course of the field.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was Nicolas Bourbaki, and why was his application to the American Mathematical Society rejected in the 1950s? Options: A. He was a mathematician who did not exist as a person and was therefore rejected for this reason., B. He was a mathematician who rejected the American Mathematical Society's offer to join., C. He was a Russian mathematician who refused to collaborate with the American Mathematical Society., D. He was a French mathematician who was too old to join the American Mathematical Society. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What was the main problem that the group of French mathematicians faced while studying at the École normale supérieure in 1934? Options: A. The textbooks for their calculus class were disjointed and difficult to understand., B. The group was too small to make a significant impact on the field of mathematics., C. The mathematicians were too young to contribute to the field., D. The lack of a shared mathematical language made it difficult to share or expand their work. Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the result of the group's project to create a consistent logical framework unifying every branch of mathematics? Options: A. The "Éléments de mathématique" was a treatise that sought to create a consistent logical framework unifying every branch of mathematics., B. The group created a new branch of mathematics that was separate from the existing branches., C. The group's work was too complex and difficult to understand., D. The group's project was abandoned due to lack of interest. Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is a function, and how can it be defined? Options: A. A function is a machine that accepts inputs and produces an output., B. A function is a bridge between two groups, and it can be defined by how it maps elements across domains., C. A function is a mathematical object that can be used to solve equations., D. A function is a concept that is not well-defined in mathematics. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What are the three types of functions, and how are they defined? Options: A. Injective, surjective, and bijective functions are defined by their ability to map elements across domains., B. Injective, surjective, and bijective functions are defined by their ability to solve equations., C. Injective, surjective, and bijective functions are defined by their ability to create new mathematical objects., D. Injective, surjective, and bijective functions are not well-defined in mathematics. Correct Option: A
Question 6: Why did the group of mathematicians decide to publish their work under a collective pseudonym, Nicolas Bourbaki? Options: A. They wanted to create a new branch of mathematics that was separate from the existing branches., B. They wanted to create a consistent logical framework unifying every branch of mathematics., C. They wanted to mark the occasion of their biggest stunt yet and create a sense of mystery around their work., D. They wanted to make their work more accessible to a wider audience. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the significance of Nicolas Bourbaki's publications, and how did they become standard references in the field of mathematics? Options: A. Nicolas Bourbaki's publications were significant because they introduced new mathematical objects and concepts., B. Nicolas Bourbaki's publications were significant because they became standard references in the field of mathematics and influenced much current research., C. Nicolas Bourbaki's publications were significant because they created a new branch of mathematics that was separate from the existing branches., D. Nicolas Bourbaki's publications were not significant because they were not well-received by the mathematical community. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the final stunt that the group of mathematicians pulled off in 1968, and how did it mark the end of their joke? Options: A. They published a paper that solved a long-standing mathematical problem., B. They printed Nicolas Bourbaki's obituary, complete with mathematical puns., C. They created a new mathematical object that was named after one of their members., D. They announced that they were abandoning their project and moving on to something else. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the legacy of Nicolas Bourbaki, and how has it influenced the field of mathematics? Options: A. Nicolas Bourbaki's legacy is that he introduced new mathematical objects and concepts that are still used today., B. Nicolas Bourbaki's legacy is that he created a new branch of mathematics that is separate from the existing branches., C. Nicolas Bourbaki's legacy is that he influenced much current research and the modern emphasis on formal proofs., D. Nicolas Bourbaki's legacy is that he was not well-received by the mathematical community. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the current status of the group of mathematicians who created the pseudonym Nicolas Bourbaki, and how do they continue to influence the field of mathematics? Options: A. The group of mathematicians has disbanded and no longer contributes to the field of mathematics., B. The group of mathematicians continues to work together and publish papers under the pseudonym Nicolas Bourbaki., C. The group of mathematicians has been replaced by a new group of mathematicians who continue to work on the same projects., D. The group of mathematicians lives on today, and their legacy continues to influence much current research. Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I have identified the most similar generated MCQ as:

**Question 6: Why did the group of mathematicians decide to publish their work under a collective pseudonym, Nicolas Bourbaki?**

Although this question does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, it is the closest in terms of intent and content. The ground truth MCQ asks about what to do when you find unsatisfactory scientific explanations, and the correct option mentions forming a secret society, publishing results under a collective pseudonym, and changing the course of the field. Question 6 touches on the aspect of publishing under a collective pseudonym, which is a key part of the correct option in the ground truth MCQ.

However, if I had to choose a question that more closely matches the intent of the ground truth MCQ, I would say that none of the generated MCQs exactly match. But if I had to choose one, I would say that **Question 6** is the closest.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 2

**Transcript**:
When Nicolas Bourbaki applied 
to the American Mathematical Society in the 1950s, he was already one of the most influential
mathematicians of his time. He’d published articles 
in international journals and his textbooks were required reading. Yet his application was firmly rejected 
for one simple reason— Nicolas Bourbaki did not exist. Two decades earlier, 
mathematics was in disarray. Many established mathematicians had lost 
their lives in the first World War, and the field had become fragmented. Different branches used disparate 
methodology to pursue their own goals. And the lack of a shared 
mathematical language made it difficult to share 
or expand their work. In 1934, a group of French mathematicians 
were particularly fed up. While studying at the prestigious 
École normale supérieure, they found the textbook 
for their calculus class so disjointed that they decided to write a better one. The small group 
quickly took on new members, and as the project grew, 
so did their ambition. The result was 
the "Éléments de mathématique," a treatise that sought to create 
a consistent logical framework unifying every branch of mathematics. The text began 
with a set of simple axioms— laws and assumptions it would use 
to build its argument. From there, its authors derived 
more and more complex theorems that corresponded with work 
being done across the field. But to truly reveal common ground, the group needed to identify 
consistent rules that applied to a wide range of problems. To accomplish this, they gave new, 
clear definitions to some of the most important 
mathematical objects, including the function. It’s reasonable to think of functions 
as machines that accept inputs and produce an output. But if we think of functions 
as bridges between two groups, we can start to make claims about 
the logical relationships between them. For example, consider a group of numbers
and a group of letters. We could define a function where 
every numerical input corresponds to the same alphabetical output, but this doesn’t establish 
a particularly interesting relationship. Alternatively, we could define a function 
where every numerical input corresponds to a different 
alphabetical output. This second function sets up 
a logical relationship where performing a process on the input 
has corresponding effects on its mapped output. The group began to define functions by how
they mapped elements across domains. If a function’s output came 
from a unique input, they defined it as injective. If every output can be mapped 
onto at least one input, the function was surjective. And in bijective functions, each element 
had perfect one to one correspondence. This allowed mathematicians to establish 
logic that could be translated across the function’s domains 
in both directions. Their systematic approach 
to abstract principles was in stark contrast to the popular 
belief that math was an intuitive science, and an over-dependence on logic 
constrained creativity. But this rebellious band of scholars 
gleefully ignored conventional wisdom. They were revolutionizing the field, 
and they wanted to mark the occasion with their biggest stunt yet. They decided to publish 
"Éléments de mathématique" and all their subsequent work 
under a collective pseudonym: Nicolas Bourbaki. Over the next two decades, Bourbaki’s 
publications became standard references. And the group’s members took their prank 
as seriously as their work. Their invented mathematician claimed 
to be a reclusive Russian genius who would only meet 
with his selected collaborators. They sent telegrams in Bourbaki’s name, 
announced his daughter’s wedding, and publicly insulted anyone 
who doubted his existence. In 1968, when they could 
no longer maintain the ruse, the group ended their joke 
the only way they could. They printed Bourbaki’s obituary,
complete with mathematical puns. Despite his apparent death, the group 
bearing Bourbaki’s name lives on today. Though he’s not associated 
with any single major discovery, Bourbaki’s influence informs 
much current research. And the modern emphasis on formal proofs
owes a great deal to his rigorous methods. Nicolas Bourbaki may have been imaginary— 
but his legacy is very real.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Nicholas Bourbaki was a
Options: A. real mathematician, B. hoax, C. collective pseudonym, D. physicist
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When Nicolas Bourbaki applied 
to the American Mathematical Society in the 1950s, he was already one of the most influential
mathematicians of his time. He’d published articles 
in international journals and his textbooks were required reading. Yet his application was firmly rejected 
for one simple reason— Nicolas Bourbaki did not exist. Two decades earlier, 
mathematics was in disarray. Many established mathematicians had lost 
their lives in the first World War, and the field had become fragmented. Different branches used disparate 
methodology to pursue their own goals. And the lack of a shared 
mathematical language made it difficult to share 
or expand their work. In 1934, a group of French mathematicians 
were particularly fed up. While studying at the prestigious 
École normale supérieure, they found the textbook 
for their calculus class so disjointed that they decided to write a better one. The small group 
quickly took on new members, and as the project grew, 
so did their ambition. The result was 
the "Éléments de mathématique," a treatise that sought to create 
a consistent logical framework unifying every branch of mathematics. The text began 
with a set of simple axioms— laws and assumptions it would use 
to build its argument. From there, its authors derived 
more and more complex theorems that corresponded with work 
being done across the field. But to truly reveal common ground, the group needed to identify 
consistent rules that applied to a wide range of problems. To accomplish this, they gave new, 
clear definitions to some of the most important 
mathematical objects, including the function. It’s reasonable to think of functions 
as machines that accept inputs and produce an output. But if we think of functions 
as bridges between two groups, we can start to make claims about 
the logical relationships between them. For example, consider a group of numbers
and a group of letters. We could define a function where 
every numerical input corresponds to the same alphabetical output, but this doesn’t establish 
a particularly interesting relationship. Alternatively, we could define a function 
where every numerical input corresponds to a different 
alphabetical output. This second function sets up 
a logical relationship where performing a process on the input 
has corresponding effects on its mapped output. The group began to define functions by how
they mapped elements across domains. If a function’s output came 
from a unique input, they defined it as injective. If every output can be mapped 
onto at least one input, the function was surjective. And in bijective functions, each element 
had perfect one to one correspondence. This allowed mathematicians to establish 
logic that could be translated across the function’s domains 
in both directions. Their systematic approach 
to abstract principles was in stark contrast to the popular 
belief that math was an intuitive science, and an over-dependence on logic 
constrained creativity. But this rebellious band of scholars 
gleefully ignored conventional wisdom. They were revolutionizing the field, 
and they wanted to mark the occasion with their biggest stunt yet. They decided to publish 
"Éléments de mathématique" and all their subsequent work 
under a collective pseudonym: Nicolas Bourbaki. Over the next two decades, Bourbaki’s 
publications became standard references. And the group’s members took their prank 
as seriously as their work. Their invented mathematician claimed 
to be a reclusive Russian genius who would only meet 
with his selected collaborators. They sent telegrams in Bourbaki’s name, 
announced his daughter’s wedding, and publicly insulted anyone 
who doubted his existence. In 1968, when they could 
no longer maintain the ruse, the group ended their joke 
the only way they could. They printed Bourbaki’s obituary,
complete with mathematical puns. Despite his apparent death, the group 
bearing Bourbaki’s name lives on today. Though he’s not associated 
with any single major discovery, Bourbaki’s influence informs 
much current research. And the modern emphasis on formal proofs
owes a great deal to his rigorous methods. Nicolas Bourbaki may have been imaginary— 
but his legacy is very real.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is an injective function?
Options: A. Where all elements that can be obtained in the set of outputs – can be traced to a unique element in the set of inputs, B. Where all elements that can be obtained in the set of outputs – cannot be traced to a unique element in the set of inputs, C. All elements in the set of outputs can be traced to one or more elements in the set of inputs
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was Nicolas Bourbaki, and why was his application to the American Mathematical Society rejected in the 1950s? Options: A. He was a mathematician who did not exist as a person and was therefore rejected for this reason., B. He was a mathematician who rejected the American Mathematical Society's offer to join., C. He was a Russian mathematician who refused to collaborate with the American Mathematical Society., D. He was a French mathematician who was too old to join the American Mathematical Society. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What was the main problem that the group of French mathematicians faced while studying at the École normale supérieure in 1934? Options: A. The textbooks for their calculus class were disjointed and difficult to understand., B. The group was too small to make a significant impact on the field of mathematics., C. The mathematicians were too young to contribute to the field., D. The lack of a shared mathematical language made it difficult to share or expand their work. Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the result of the group's project to create a consistent logical framework unifying every branch of mathematics? Options: A. The "Éléments de mathématique" was a treatise that sought to create a consistent logical framework unifying every branch of mathematics., B. The group created a new branch of mathematics that was separate from the existing branches., C. The group's work was too complex and difficult to understand., D. The group's project was abandoned due to lack of interest. Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is a function, and how can it be defined? Options: A. A function is a machine that accepts inputs and produces an output., B. A function is a bridge between two groups, and it can be defined by how it maps elements across domains., C. A function is a mathematical object that can be used to solve equations., D. A function is a concept that is not well-defined in mathematics. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What are the three types of functions, and how are they defined? Options: A. Injective, surjective, and bijective functions are defined by their ability to map elements across domains., B. Injective, surjective, and bijective functions are defined by their ability to solve equations., C. Injective, surjective, and bijective functions are defined by their ability to create new mathematical objects., D. Injective, surjective, and bijective functions are not well-defined in mathematics. Correct Option: A
Question 6: Why did the group of mathematicians decide to publish their work under a collective pseudonym, Nicolas Bourbaki? Options: A. They wanted to create a new branch of mathematics that was separate from the existing branches., B. They wanted to create a consistent logical framework unifying every branch of mathematics., C. They wanted to mark the occasion of their biggest stunt yet and create a sense of mystery around their work., D. They wanted to make their work more accessible to a wider audience. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the significance of Nicolas Bourbaki's publications, and how did they become standard references in the field of mathematics? Options: A. Nicolas Bourbaki's publications were significant because they introduced new mathematical objects and concepts., B. Nicolas Bourbaki's publications were significant because they became standard references in the field of mathematics and influenced much current research., C. Nicolas Bourbaki's publications were significant because they created a new branch of mathematics that was separate from the existing branches., D. Nicolas Bourbaki's publications were not significant because they were not well-received by the mathematical community. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the final stunt that the group of mathematicians pulled off in 1968, and how did it mark the end of their joke? Options: A. They published a paper that solved a long-standing mathematical problem., B. They printed Nicolas Bourbaki's obituary, complete with mathematical puns., C. They created a new mathematical object that was named after one of their members., D. They announced that they were abandoning their project and moving on to something else. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the legacy of Nicolas Bourbaki, and how has it influenced the field of mathematics? Options: A. Nicolas Bourbaki's legacy is that he introduced new mathematical objects and concepts that are still used today., B. Nicolas Bourbaki's legacy is that he created a new branch of mathematics that is separate from the existing branches., C. Nicolas Bourbaki's legacy is that he influenced much current research and the modern emphasis on formal proofs., D. Nicolas Bourbaki's legacy is that he was not well-received by the mathematical community. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the current status of the group of mathematicians who created the pseudonym Nicolas Bourbaki, and how do they continue to influence the field of mathematics? Options: A. The group of mathematicians has disbanded and no longer contributes to the field of mathematics., B. The group of mathematicians continues to work together and publish papers under the pseudonym Nicolas Bourbaki., C. The group of mathematicians has been replaced by a new group of mathematicians who continue to work on the same projects., D. The group of mathematicians lives on today, and their legacy continues to influence much current research. Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

This question is about the definition of functions, specifically injective, surjective, and bijective functions, which aligns with the ground truth MCQ's focus on the definition of an injective function. Although the generated MCQ is broader in scope, covering three types of functions, it demonstrates a similar intent and content to the ground truth MCQ.

**Transcript**:
When Nicolas Bourbaki applied 
to the American Mathematical Society in the 1950s, he was already one of the most influential
mathematicians of his time. He’d published articles 
in international journals and his textbooks were required reading. Yet his application was firmly rejected 
for one simple reason— Nicolas Bourbaki did not exist. Two decades earlier, 
mathematics was in disarray. Many established mathematicians had lost 
their lives in the first World War, and the field had become fragmented. Different branches used disparate 
methodology to pursue their own goals. And the lack of a shared 
mathematical language made it difficult to share 
or expand their work. In 1934, a group of French mathematicians 
were particularly fed up. While studying at the prestigious 
École normale supérieure, they found the textbook 
for their calculus class so disjointed that they decided to write a better one. The small group 
quickly took on new members, and as the project grew, 
so did their ambition. The result was 
the "Éléments de mathématique," a treatise that sought to create 
a consistent logical framework unifying every branch of mathematics. The text began 
with a set of simple axioms— laws and assumptions it would use 
to build its argument. From there, its authors derived 
more and more complex theorems that corresponded with work 
being done across the field. But to truly reveal common ground, the group needed to identify 
consistent rules that applied to a wide range of problems. To accomplish this, they gave new, 
clear definitions to some of the most important 
mathematical objects, including the function. It’s reasonable to think of functions 
as machines that accept inputs and produce an output. But if we think of functions 
as bridges between two groups, we can start to make claims about 
the logical relationships between them. For example, consider a group of numbers
and a group of letters. We could define a function where 
every numerical input corresponds to the same alphabetical output, but this doesn’t establish 
a particularly interesting relationship. Alternatively, we could define a function 
where every numerical input corresponds to a different 
alphabetical output. This second function sets up 
a logical relationship where performing a process on the input 
has corresponding effects on its mapped output. The group began to define functions by how
they mapped elements across domains. If a function’s output came 
from a unique input, they defined it as injective. If every output can be mapped 
onto at least one input, the function was surjective. And in bijective functions, each element 
had perfect one to one correspondence. This allowed mathematicians to establish 
logic that could be translated across the function’s domains 
in both directions. Their systematic approach 
to abstract principles was in stark contrast to the popular 
belief that math was an intuitive science, and an over-dependence on logic 
constrained creativity. But this rebellious band of scholars 
gleefully ignored conventional wisdom. They were revolutionizing the field, 
and they wanted to mark the occasion with their biggest stunt yet. They decided to publish 
"Éléments de mathématique" and all their subsequent work 
under a collective pseudonym: Nicolas Bourbaki. Over the next two decades, Bourbaki’s 
publications became standard references. And the group’s members took their prank 
as seriously as their work. Their invented mathematician claimed 
to be a reclusive Russian genius who would only meet 
with his selected collaborators. They sent telegrams in Bourbaki’s name, 
announced his daughter’s wedding, and publicly insulted anyone 
who doubted his existence. In 1968, when they could 
no longer maintain the ruse, the group ended their joke 
the only way they could. They printed Bourbaki’s obituary,
complete with mathematical puns. Despite his apparent death, the group 
bearing Bourbaki’s name lives on today. Though he’s not associated 
with any single major discovery, Bourbaki’s influence informs 
much current research. And the modern emphasis on formal proofs
owes a great deal to his rigorous methods. Nicolas Bourbaki may have been imaginary— 
but his legacy is very real.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 5

**Transcript**:
When Nicolas Bourbaki applied 
to the American Mathematical Society in the 1950s, he was already one of the most influential
mathematicians of his time. He’d published articles 
in international journals and his textbooks were required reading. Yet his application was firmly rejected 
for one simple reason— Nicolas Bourbaki did not exist. Two decades earlier, 
mathematics was in disarray. Many established mathematicians had lost 
their lives in the first World War, and the field had become fragmented. Different branches used disparate 
methodology to pursue their own goals. And the lack of a shared 
mathematical language made it difficult to share 
or expand their work. In 1934, a group of French mathematicians 
were particularly fed up. While studying at the prestigious 
École normale supérieure, they found the textbook 
for their calculus class so disjointed that they decided to write a better one. The small group 
quickly took on new members, and as the project grew, 
so did their ambition. The result was 
the "Éléments de mathématique," a treatise that sought to create 
a consistent logical framework unifying every branch of mathematics. The text began 
with a set of simple axioms— laws and assumptions it would use 
to build its argument. From there, its authors derived 
more and more complex theorems that corresponded with work 
being done across the field. But to truly reveal common ground, the group needed to identify 
consistent rules that applied to a wide range of problems. To accomplish this, they gave new, 
clear definitions to some of the most important 
mathematical objects, including the function. It’s reasonable to think of functions 
as machines that accept inputs and produce an output. But if we think of functions 
as bridges between two groups, we can start to make claims about 
the logical relationships between them. For example, consider a group of numbers
and a group of letters. We could define a function where 
every numerical input corresponds to the same alphabetical output, but this doesn’t establish 
a particularly interesting relationship. Alternatively, we could define a function 
where every numerical input corresponds to a different 
alphabetical output. This second function sets up 
a logical relationship where performing a process on the input 
has corresponding effects on its mapped output. The group began to define functions by how
they mapped elements across domains. If a function’s output came 
from a unique input, they defined it as injective. If every output can be mapped 
onto at least one input, the function was surjective. And in bijective functions, each element 
had perfect one to one correspondence. This allowed mathematicians to establish 
logic that could be translated across the function’s domains 
in both directions. Their systematic approach 
to abstract principles was in stark contrast to the popular 
belief that math was an intuitive science, and an over-dependence on logic 
constrained creativity. But this rebellious band of scholars 
gleefully ignored conventional wisdom. They were revolutionizing the field, 
and they wanted to mark the occasion with their biggest stunt yet. They decided to publish 
"Éléments de mathématique" and all their subsequent work 
under a collective pseudonym: Nicolas Bourbaki. Over the next two decades, Bourbaki’s 
publications became standard references. And the group’s members took their prank 
as seriously as their work. Their invented mathematician claimed 
to be a reclusive Russian genius who would only meet 
with his selected collaborators. They sent telegrams in Bourbaki’s name, 
announced his daughter’s wedding, and publicly insulted anyone 
who doubted his existence. In 1968, when they could 
no longer maintain the ruse, the group ended their joke 
the only way they could. They printed Bourbaki’s obituary,
complete with mathematical puns. Despite his apparent death, the group 
bearing Bourbaki’s name lives on today. Though he’s not associated 
with any single major discovery, Bourbaki’s influence informs 
much current research. And the modern emphasis on formal proofs
owes a great deal to his rigorous methods. Nicolas Bourbaki may have been imaginary— 
but his legacy is very real.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is a bijective function?
Options: A. Where all outputs that can be obtained – can be traced to a unique input, B. Where all outputs that can be obtained – cannot be traced to a unique input, C. All elements in the set of outputs can be traced to one or more elements in the set of inputs, D. A function that is injective as well as surjective
Correct Option: D
